Men have largely not been prioritised for PrEP in sub-Saharan Africa, except for men in serodifferent couples and men who have sex with men.
23 Yet, one-third of new HIV diagnoses in our study region are among men.
9 We found substantial PrEP uptake among men, who comprised half of the individuals who initiated PrEP. In our qualitative work, we have found high levels of interest in PrEP among men, particularly among those in concurrent partnerships, and found that men typically face fewer barriers to PrEP adoption (eg, partner permission) than women.
19 Our approach to PrEP service delivery, with out-of-facility options for PrEP initiation and follow-up, might have fostered uptake among men, for whom clinic attendance might pose a barrier to HIV testing and prevention services.
24 Men are a crucial link in transmission networks,
25 and expanding their prevention options could accelerate incidence reductions in generalised epidemics.
